['Leerdoelen', 'In het onderzoekscollege wordt het wetenschappelijke fundament gelegd voor de bachelorscriptie Europese Studies. De student verkrijgt een overzicht van de wetenschappelijke literatuur, de onderzoeksvragen en onderzoeksmethoden die kenmerkend zijn voor een bepaald onderzoeksthema. De student leert zelfstandig literatuuronderzoek uit te voeren, hetgeen resulteert een overzichtswerkstuk over de literatuur, de onderzoeksvragen en onderzoeksmethoden van het thema van het onderzoekscollege. Daarnaast werkt de student onder begeleiding van de docent aan het opstellen van een onderzoeksvoorstel voor de bachelorscriptie, door een onderzoeksvraag op te stellen en te motiveren, het uit te voeren onderzoek te beschrijven, en het opstellen van een voorlopige hoofdstukindeling en literatuurlijst.', 'Inhoud', 'Deze cursus behandelt de methodiek en de theorie van onderzoek naar nationalisme in een historische en hedendaagse context. Hoe denken de meest toonaangevende wetenschappers over nationalisme?\xa0 Welke benaderingen zijn het meest geschikt voor scripties over nationaal denken en culturele identiteit?', 'In de afgelopen twee eeuwen heeft het nationalisme als ideologie de boventoon gevoerd in cultuur en maatschappij, en tevens in het politieke en economische denken. Na het uiteenvallen van de grote Europese rijken ontstonden verschillende natiestaten. Deze legitimeerden hun bestaan door de strijd voor modernisering, door een beroep op het mandaat van de volkswil, en door een eigen invulling van de geschiedenis. Daarbij werd de natie als een homogene entiteit met eeuwige normen en waarden afgebeeld. Ondanks globalisering en de eenheidsgedachte van de Europese Unie oefent die erfenis van het nationalisme nog steeds een sterke invloed uit op het identiteitsbesef van de Europese burger. Tegenwoordig is het idee van de natie veelvuldig onderwerp van wetenschappelijke en politieke debatten. In de wetenschappelijke\xa0 analyse van het nationaal denken is het accent verschoven van een\xa0 intra-nationale kijk op de natie naar een meer vergelijkend en transnationaal perspectief. Daarbij spelen begrippen zoals cultuurtransfer (culturele overdracht) en cultureel geheugen een centrale rol.', 'Een transnationaal vergelijkende invalshoek, zoals die uitgerekend in de Europese Studies kan worden toegepast, geeft ons vaak een beter inzicht in de complexe culturele en politieke Europese werkelijkheid. Staten hebben multi-etnische gebieden genationaliseerd, en zowel dat proces als de uitkomst daarvan waren en blijven een bron van conflicten. Cultuurgrenzen vallen nooit samen met landsgrenzen. Binnen bestaande naties zijn er vaak verschillende regionale of etnische loyaliteiten – sommige traditioneel-provinciaal, andere modern-stedelijk (als gevolg van migratiepatronen in de laatste 50 jaar). Hoe gaan we om met dubbele nationaliteiten of de zogenaamde “hyphenated identities”? In\xa0 de publieke sfeer zijn er vaak heftige meningsverschillen en debatten over nationale symbolen en identiteiten. Wie hoort bij een natie en wie hoort er niet bij? Hoe stabiel zijn de kenmerken van nationale identiteit? Tot op welke hoogte kunnen natie-staten hun soevereiniteit en hun zogenaamde “identiteit” overdragen aan grotere verbanden? In deze cursus komen zulke vragen aan de orde met als doel het ontwikkelen van een succesvol scriptieonderwerp.', 'Werkvorm', 'Seminars: colleges bestaan uit een korte inleiding gevolgd door actieve groepsdiscussie over voorgeschreven teksten.', 'Rooster', 'Zie het rooster van dit vak op http://rooster.uva.nl', 'Studiemateriaal', 'ANDERSON, Benedict: Imagined Communities, London-New York: Verso, 2003, pp. 1-46, 67-111, 141-154.', 'ASSMANN, Aleida: Cultural Memory and Western Civilization, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011.', 'ERLL, Astrid: Memory in Culture, London: Palgrave Macmillan, 2011.', 'ERLL, Astrid-Nünning, Ansgar: A Companion to Cultural Memory Studies, Berlin-New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2010.', 'GELLNER, Ernest: Nationlism, London, Phoenix, 1997.', 'HOBSBAWM, Eric and Ranger, Terence: The Invention of Tradition, Cambridge: Canto, 2003, pp. 1-43, 101-164.', 'LEERSSEN, Joep: National Thought in Europe, Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2006.', "NORA, P.: 'Between Memory and History: Les Lieux de Mémoire', Representations 26, 1989, 7–25.", 'SMITH, Anthony D.: Nationalism, Cambridge: Polity Press, Key Concepts, 2005.', 'VERTOVEC, Steven: Transnationalism, Oxon: Routledge, 2009.', 'Toetsing en toetsdata', 'Overzichtswerkstuk (100% van het eindcijfer) en Scriptievoorstel (AVV).']

['Objectives', 'The student can sum up the concepts behind the adaptive cycle model of changeThe student can recognize the different roles of management in the phases of the adaptive cycle model and what roles information and information management plays in facilitating the managerThe student can illustrate how an organization in crisis can be better understood by using the adaptive cycle of change-model.The student can recognize the roles of new forms of (virtual) co-operation between organizations to deal with dynamic changes in the environmentThe student knows the concepts and methodologiesThe student can illustrate how the context (life conditions) and the individual worldview – resulting in an actual system of values and norms – can lead to actual behaviorThe student is able, using the above mentioned knowledge and insights - to comment on practical cases in organizations', 'Contents', 'Organizations will inevitably go through phases in their development in a dynamic context. In discussing these phases we will indicate their characteristics, so that they can be recognized and predicted. In addition, we indicate the sequence of phases and we will focus on the transitions between the phases. Consequently, specific success factors for organizational change can be derived and we will focus on the role of Information (management) and the information manager in the success of organizational change processes.', 'Aside from the impact of the dynamic context on the organization itself, the fact that the organization is part of a chain or network of organizations will influence the way of collaborating. These relationships will in many cases have a temporary character. In that respect we often speak of virtual network environments of virtual breeding environments. These concepts will be introduced and elaborated.', 'The approach in the course will be compared with existing theories in the literature on organizational change. The following topics will be studied:', 'Introduction and setting the sceneThe adaptive cycle as method for organizational changeVirtual organizations breeding environmentsVirtual organizationsHumans, culture and working together in teamsThe Cynefin FrameworkRoundup and student lectures', 'Registration', 'Registration is required via https://www.sis.uva.nl until four weeks before the start of the semester.', 'Teaching method', 'The course will be taught in the form of lectures (2h/w) and working groups (4h/w)', 'Study materials', 'Will be made available via Blackboard', 'As a starting point extra literature can be found\xa0using two sources:', 'http://www.adaptivecycle.nl This wiki has been used the last three years for the same course and gives an overview of the almost 170 articles on organizations and organizational changehttp://www.fcngroup.nl This is the site of the Federated Collaborative Networks (FCN) research group led by Prof dr Hamideh Afsarmanesh.', 'Assessment and testing', 'Students will have to do a mini-research project on a specific topic on the field of (virtual) organizations in a dynamic context. The results of this mini research project will have to be presentes in de form of a student lecture.To experience the impact of the theories that will be studied on real organizations a mini case study should be conductedAn exam will take place.']

['Objectives', 'The student will get insight in the aims, methods and recent results in the field of linguistics and, more in particular, its position in the field of cognitive science.', 'Contents', "Always wanted to know what linguistics was all about? Got afraid of 'tree-structures' in Chomskian style during your first year Introduction? Nevertheless, had the feeling that something interesting might be going on? Here is your answer: a linguistics course for the non-specialist. In this course a number of topics and questions that are currently subject to linguistic debate will be introduced and discussed. Such topics include discussions as to whether human language really affects perception and culture (addressing myths such as that the Hopi do not perceive time because their language does not have tense). We will also addresses properties that may uniquely characterize human language. We also discuss the autonomy of language as a cognitive function, and how this function may have taken shape in the course of evolution. Also, some time will be spent on how current ideas are grounded in the linguistic tradition of the past 50 years. We will approach these issues without assuming any previous technical linguistic knowledge. ['Objectives', 'The skills we train are: analysis of complex historical developments and critical writing; disciplined discussion and asking good questions. In the work groups we will read original documents that allow us to go into depth with issues introduced in the lecture. Also film material will put you into the shoes of Soviet citizens and their leaders. Students will regularly write short summaries of texts and documents, and develop a well-defined individual research project culminating in a term paper. While teaching is in English (as are all class readings), you can submit your written assignments also in Dutch or German.', 'Contents', 'No country has witnessed the kind of upheavals and transformations that Russia underwent in the twentieth century. The history of modern Russia is fascinating, inspiring, horrifying, but never boring. This course will introduce students to the modern history of Russia from the late imperial period to the present day. course_title: A City full of Gods: Religion in Athenian Democracy
text: ['Contents', "In ancient Greek poleis, the gods were an integral part of society. Although radical thinkers occasionally toyed with atheism in thought experiments, the presence of the gods was simply a given in daily life. From major gods like Demeter to local healing heroes, each had needs and desires, moods and sympathies, just like mortals; but without mortality to put a check on the gods' whims, those mortals had to spend a significant portion of their time and resources on keeping the gods satisfied.", 'This basic fact will be the starting point for our study of classical Athenian democracy. How did the presence of the gods affect the development of democratic ideology and practice ? In this course, we will study a variety of historical, literary and archeological sources to trace how religion shaped\xa0the democratic institutions and politics of classical Athens', 'Registration', 'Through SIS-UvA, from 3 December (8 hrs) to 16 December (13 hrs). course_title: A crisis of centre parties or a crisis of democracy?
text: ['Objectives', 'Obtaining knowledge of state of the art of literature on party system change Obtaining the ability to critically evaluate empirical research Obtaining the ability to conduct research Improve writing skills', 'Contents', 'Modern representative democracies are party democracies. Some would go as far as Schattschneider (1942), who argued that “Political parties created modern democracy and modern democracy is unthinkable save in terms of parties”. Yet, there are good reasons to think that contemporary party democracy is facing a crisis. Over the past two decades, parties with governing potential have lost support to populist or extremist parties of the left and right, or to protest parties without an ideological profile, such as Pirate Parties, or Beppe Grillo’s movement. We have seen these developments in almost all established democracies, except for a country like the US, where the electoral system prevents the rise of new parties, but where a radical opposition movement organised itself within one of the mainstream parties. Other empirically observable indicators of the crisis of electoral democracy are decreasing turnout and low levels of trust in political parties. On top of this, we are witnessing an economic crisis, which makes is highly unlikely that the mainstream parties will be able to restore citizens’ confidence in their problem solving capacities.', 'For a long time, party democracy worked well, because, in the words of Peter Mair (2007) it provided the synthesis between popular democracy and constitutional democracy. Yet, centre parties are facing some fundamental challenges. The first challenge is that their capacity to influence policies have been reduced by the rise of supranational organisations and by the constraints of an increasingly globalised economy. Secondly,\xa0 processes of individualisation and emancipation of voters have made electorates increasingly volatile and parties more uncertain. Third, media fragmentation makes communication with voters increasingly difficult. As a consequence of all these developments, we may be witnessing a growing gap in modern party democracy between highly responsive outsider parties on the one hand and increasingly unresponsive and responsible parties of government on the other, as argued by Mair. He suggested that if parties are failing, and if modern democracy cannot exist without parties, we may soon see the end of democracy as we know it. Others are more optimistic.', 'In this seminar we will discuss recent theoretical contributions and empirical studies dealing with various aspects of the functioning of electoral democracy.', 'Registration', 'During the registration period: Monday 6 October 08:30 and Friday 10 October 13:00.', 'You can find this course either by title or by code 7324A126I', 'Teaching method', 'Student presentations and group discussion', 'Contact hours', 'Course weekTeaching methodHours/weekRemarks1 - 8Werkcollege4These contact hours are approximate and do not include hours for assignments, hours for reading, etc. Extra classes may be planned in January. text: ['Objectives', 'Students:', 'Are able to grasp the processes of ethnic-political integration and fragmentation in Europe, ranging from the evolution of the European Union to ethno-regionalism and nationalism;Are able to assess policy documents and political opinions critically;Are able to apply their knowledge and insights to the development of a policy statement;Have the communication skills to participate in a collective decision making process.', 'This course contributes to the following exit qualifications of the Bachelor Sociale Geografie en Planologie: K1,K6, K7, K8,K9, \xa0K10, K11, K18, T1, T4, T5, T6, T7, T8, T9-12, O1, O2, C1, C2, C3, C4, L1,L3', 'Contents', 'This course introduces the students to the political geography of the European Union. course_title: "Gentlemen Don’t Read Each Other’s Mail": United States Intelligence and National Security
text: ['Objectives', 'Introduce students to the challenges of intelligence analysis;Analyze the history of American concepts of national security and United States intelligence activities abroad;Study the rights and freedoms of citizens in the United States and the history of American domestic intelligence activities;Evaluate the role of the U.S. President and the uses of intelligence organizations and intelligence information.', 'Contents', 'This lecture series brings together the themes national security and the right on privacy, two topics with a long history of debate, through the focus of United States intelligence work. Intelligence organizations are supposed to protect the nation against strategic and surprise attacks. The prevention of surprise attacks regularly failed, and in sometimes spectacular ways, such as with the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 and the 9/11 attacks in 2001. We will analyze what intelligence organizations try and can achieve, and how American politicians respond to so-called intelligence failures. One type of response is to increase intelligence activities, and gather more information on individual Americans. Such activities lead to questions about the role and power of the state, and the right to privacy. The Bill of Rights, and notably the Fourth Amendment, plays an important role in the discussion about the right of American citizens to their freedom and the permissibility of the activities of intelligence organizations. The focus of the course is on twentieth and twenty-first century events, when organizations like the FBI, CIA, and NSA came into existence and defined American intelligence activities. The role and activities of intelligence institutions is determined by the political context in which they function, and therefore the organization of the American political system will also be discussed. The course does not only deal with the American domestic debate on intelligence, but is also about American intelligence activities abroad, ranging from covert actions to change the political balance in other nations, to efforts to check the on-line and cell phone activities of individuals globally.As part of the course, students will write two papers based on either an FBI or CIA report, to gain insight into the quality of intelligence reports, but also into the challenges to gain reliable research results.', 'Registration', 'Through SIS-UvA, from Tuesday 18 June 00.08 hrs to Friday 3 July 15.00 hrs.', 'Teaching method', 'Lectures - on average 2 contact hours per week.', 'Time', 'See the timetable of this course on https://rooster.uva.nl.Check the timetable before going to class, in case of changes.', 'Study materials', 'Mark M. Lowenthal, Intelligence: From Secrets to Policy. (Washington, DC: CQ Press, 2015), 6th edition (no earlier editions !), available in hardbound, paperback, and digital editions.Readings from the UvA digital library.', 'Cost', 'About 55 Euro.', 'Assessment and testing', 'Your final grade will be based on two tests (each 25% of the final grade or 50% total), and two written assignments (1500 and 2500 words, respectively 20% and 30% of your final grade). To pass you have to have a 5,5 grade average for the tests and for the final average grade (which includes the grades for the written assignments). There will be no make up options for the papers.', 'In the case of the tests, there will be a make-up test that covers the material of both previous tests (which means you cannot do a make up test for just one of the exams).', 'The questions on the exam will be based on the mandatory literature and the content of the lectures.', 'Remarks', 'Please note the requirement for enrolling in this course.']

course_title: 'De Geuzen voor Madrid'. Nederlanders in de Internationale Brigade tijdens de Spaanse Burgeroorlog.
text: ['Leerdoelen', 'Verwerven van kennis en inzicht in:', 'De historiografie van de Spaanse Burgeroorlog en de rol van de Internationale Brigades daarinTheorievorming rondom ‘foreign fighters’', 'Verdiepen van vaardigheden in:', 'Het kritisch lezen en beoordelen van wetenschappelijke tekstenHet formuleren van een relevante probleemstelling binnen een breder onderzoekskaderHet samenwerken aan een historisch project in groepsverbandHet zoeken en selecteren van relevante historische literatuur en archiefmateriaalHet schrijven van korte stukken op basis van historisch onderzoek, specifiek bedoeld voor het internet', 'Inhoud', 'Wat in juli 1936 begon als een opstand van een stel ontevreden Spaanse officieren tegen de linkse Tweede Republiek, escaleerde door interventie van Nazi-Duitsland en fascistisch Italië tot een burgeroorlog met een internationaal-politieke dimensie. Overal in de wereld kwamen, met name in linkse en uitgesproken antifascistische kringen, spontaan steunbewegingen op om de Spaanse Republiek te redden. Sommige van hen waren zelfs bereid te vechten voor dat ideaal. Zij togen op eigen houtje naar Spanje en organiseerden zich in vrijwillige legereenheden en min of meer op eigen houtje de strijd aanbonden met de ‘fascisten van Franco’. Deze gewapende internationale solidariteit kreeg een belangrijke impuls toen de Komintern, het door de politieke leiders van de Sovjet-Unie gedomineerde samenwerkingsverband van communistische partijen, besloten om de werving, training en organisatie van dit idealistische vreemdelingenlegioen op zich te nemen. De ‘Internationale Brigade’ groeide daarna ut tot zo’n 35.0000 man én vrouw, waaronder ook zo’n 800 Nederlanders.', 'In dit college onderzoeken we de oorlogservaringen van deze Nederlandse ‘Interbrigadiers’ in dit internationale leger. Belangrijk daarbij is dat de westerse regeringen, waaronder de Nederlanders, in een poging om het conflict te isoleren en zo een tweede Wereldoorlog te voorkomen, elke inmenging van buitenaf als onwenselijk beschouwden en interventie daarom actief vervolgden. Dat betekent dat, in tegenstelling tot een regulier soldaat, deze interbrigadiers kozen voor een gevaarlijk avontuur waarbij ze, zelfs als ze heelhuids thuis kwamen, zware gevangenisstraffen riskeerden, hun nationaliteit verloren, en de rest van hun leven door de geheime diensten werden geschaduwd als staatsgevaarlijke elementen in dienst van Moskou. Daarnaast was de Internationale Brigade ook bepaald geen regulier leger. Het was een samenraapsel van allerhande nationaliteiten en dito militaire doctrines, ervaringen en wapensystemen, die op alle niveaus zorgden voor voorbeelden van niet alleen wonderbaarlijke internationale verbroedering en opofferingsgezindheid, maar ook van Babylonische spraakverwarring.', 'Aan de hand van concrete case studies onderzoeken we in dit college waarom Nederlandse Interbrigadiers kozen voor dit gevaarlijke avontuur, hoe zij training, politieke ‘instructie’ door de Komintern, en hun positie binnen de Spaanse Republiek ervoeren, op welke manier en in welke context zij militair werden ingezet, en hoe werd omgegaan met salariëring, verlof, logistiek, en andere zaken die in een ‘regulier’ leger vanzelfsprekend geacht worden te zijn. Want alleen door te begrijpen hoe zo’n leger functioneert en waarom mensen kiezen voor zo’n onzeker bestaan, kunnen we iets snappen van hedendaagse ‘foreign fighters’ zoals de Nederlanders die vechten voor de Islamitische Staat.', 'We leggen op twee manieren verslag van onze bevindingen:', 'een uitgebreid onderzoeksverslag op basis van primair bronmateriaal, waarbij we in groepen aan het werk gaan.door de resultaten van ons onderzoek te verwerken in bestaande en openbaar toegankelijke digitale informatiebronnen: we gaan dus publiceren voor het web. De recente kritiek op het standaardbeeld van het logisch-positivisme als een anti-metafysisch empirisme dat is gebaseerd op het denken van figuren zoals Hume (inductie, positivisme) en Wittgenstein (verificatie) staat hierbij centraal. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan het even recente herziene beeld waarin het belang van het (neo)Kantianisme van o.a. Cassirer voor het denken van logisch-positivisten zoals Carnap en Reichenbach wordt blootgelegd.', "Anderzijds wordt tegen deze achtergrond de inmiddels beroemde uitspraak dat Kuhn met zijn Structure of Scientific Revolutions (1962) het logisch-positivisme 'vermoordde' onderzocht. ['Leerdoelen', 'In het onderzoekscollege wordt het wetenschappelijke fundament gelegd voor de bachelorscriptie Europese Studies. De student verkrijgt een overzicht van de wetenschappelijke literatuur, de onderzoeksvragen en onderzoeksmethoden die kenmerkend zijn voor een bepaald onderzoeksthema. De student leert zelfstandig literatuuronderzoek uit te voeren, hetgeen resulteert een overzichtswerkstuk over de literatuur, de onderzoeksvragen en onderzoeksmethoden van het thema van het onderzoekscollege. Daarnaast werkt de student onder begeleiding van de docent aan het opstellen van een onderzoeksvoorstel voor de bachelorscriptie, door een onderzoeksvraag op te stellen en te motiveren, het uit te voeren onderzoek te beschrijven, en het opstellen van een voorlopige hoofdstukindeling en literatuurlijst.', 'Inhoud', 'Deze cursus behandelt de methodiek en de theorie van onderzoek naar nationalisme in een historische en hedendaagse context. Hoe denken de meest toonaangevende wetenschappers over nationalisme?\xa0 Welke benaderingen zijn het meest geschikt voor scripties over nationaal denken en culturele identiteit?', 'In de afgelopen twee eeuwen heeft het nationalisme als ideologie de boventoon gevoerd in cultuur en maatschappij, en tevens in het politieke en economische denken. Na het uiteenvallen van de grote Europese rijken ontstonden verschillende natiestaten. Deze legitimeerden hun bestaan door de strijd voor modernisering, door een beroep op het mandaat van de volkswil, en door een eigen invulling van de geschiedenis. Daarbij werd de natie als een homogene entiteit met eeuwige normen en waarden afgebeeld. Ondanks globalisering en de eenheidsgedachte van de Europese Unie oefent die erfenis van het nationalisme nog steeds een sterke invloed uit op het identiteitsbesef van de Europese burger. Tegenwoordig is het idee van de natie veelvuldig onderwerp van wetenschappelijke en politieke debatten. In de wetenschappelijke\xa0 analyse van het nationaal denken is het accent verschoven van een\xa0 intra-nationale kijk op de natie naar een meer vergelijkend en transnationaal perspectief. Daarbij spelen begrippen zoals cultuurtransfer (culturele overdracht) en cultureel geheugen een centrale rol.', 'Een transnationaal vergelijkende invalshoek, zoals die uitgerekend in de Europese Studies kan worden toegepast, geeft ons vaak een beter inzicht in de complexe culturele en politieke Europese werkelijkheid. Staten hebben multi-etnische gebieden genationaliseerd, en zowel dat proces als de uitkomst daarvan waren en blijven een bron van conflicten. Cultuurgrenzen vallen nooit samen met landsgrenzen. Binnen bestaande naties zijn er vaak verschillende regionale of etnische loyaliteiten – sommige traditioneel-provinciaal, andere modern-stedelijk (als gevolg van migratiepatronen in de laatste 50 jaar). Hoe gaan we om met dubbele nationaliteiten of de zogenaamde “hyphenated identities”? In\xa0 de publieke sfeer zijn er vaak heftige meningsverschillen en debatten over nationale symbolen en identiteiten. Wie hoort bij een natie en wie hoort er niet bij? Hoe stabiel zijn de kenmerken van nationale identiteit? Tot op welke hoogte kunnen natie-staten hun soevereiniteit en hun zogenaamde “identiteit” overdragen aan grotere verbanden? In deze cursus komen zulke vragen aan de orde met als doel het ontwikkelen van een succesvol scriptieonderwerp.', 'Werkvorm', 'Seminars: colleges bestaan uit een korte inleiding gevolgd door actieve groepsdiscussie over voorgeschreven teksten.', 'Rooster', 'Zie het rooster van dit vak op http://rooster.uva.nl', 'Studiemateriaal', 'ANDERSON, Benedict: Imagined Communities, London-New York: Verso, 2003, pp. 1-46, 67-111, 141-154.', 'ASSMANN, Aleida: Cultural Memory and Western Civilization, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011.', 'ERLL, Astrid: Memory in Culture, London: Palgrave Macmillan, 2011.', 'ERLL, Astrid-Nünning, Ansgar: A Companion to Cultural Memory Studies, Berlin-New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2010.', 'GELLNER, Ernest: Nationlism, London, Phoenix, 1997.', 'HOBSBAWM, Eric and Ranger, Terence: The Invention of Tradition, Cambridge: Canto, 2003, pp. 1-43, 101-164.', 'LEERSSEN, Joep: National Thought in Europe, Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2006.', "NORA, P.: 'Between Memory and History: Les Lieux de Mémoire', Representations 26, 1989, 7–25.", 'SMITH, Anthony D.: Nationalism, Cambridge: Polity Press, Key Concepts, 2005.', 'VERTOVEC, Steven: Transnationalism, Oxon: Routledge, 2009.', 'Toetsing en toetsdata', 'Overzichtswerkstuk (100% van het eindcijfer) en Scriptievoorstel (AVV).']

['Objectives', 'The student is able to analyze environmental volatility and social change.The student is able to analyze and to evaluate how organizations, groups and individuals cope with change.The student is able to design structures for knowledge exchange between boundaries to stimulate change.The student reflects on his own coping with change and his advisory role in changing organizations.The student is able to write a vision on the literature on a topic in the field of VODC for a master thesis research proposalThe student is able to design his own professional development towards competent information professional in advisory roles.', 'Contents', 'Life is not about what you know, it’s about anticipating the unknowns.', 'This course is about theories and skills to deal with unknowns. It’s a high level master course based on literature from top journals. The papers are about processes to link environmental change to strategically coping with it and to organizational change. You’ll learn theories that are central to the Information Systems and Management discipline and deal with environmental (technological) change, strategic sense making, ICT based innovation and organizational change. These four themes are central to strategic information and innovation management. During the course you’ll discover your own role in these processes and how you can develop societal responsible change agent and advisory skills.', 'This course prepares for thesis writing by building your own interpretation based on different literature and applying it to organizational problems. In the following master course Integrating Cases and in your thesis you need to combine the two. The course ends with a solicitation for a case study that you’ll do in the Integrating Cases course. text: ['Objectives', 'Introduce students to the challenges of intelligence analysis;Analyze the history of American concepts of national security and United States intelligence activities abroad;Study the rights and freedoms of citizens in the United States and the history of American domestic intelligence activities;Evaluate the role of the U.S. President and the uses of intelligence organizations and intelligence information.', 'Contents', 'This lecture series brings together the themes national security and the right on privacy, two topics with a long history of debate, through the focus of United States intelligence work. Intelligence organizations are supposed to protect the nation against strategic and surprise attacks. The prevention of surprise attacks regularly failed, and in sometimes spectacular ways, such as with the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 and the 9/11 attacks in 2001. We will analyze what intelligence organizations try and can achieve, and how American politicians respond to so-called intelligence failures. One type of response is to increase intelligence activities, and gather more information on individual Americans. Such activities lead to questions about the role and power of the state, and the right to privacy. The Bill of Rights, and notably the Fourth Amendment, plays an important role in the discussion about the right of American citizens to their freedom and the permissibility of the activities of intelligence organizations. The focus of the course is on twentieth and twenty-first century events, when organizations like the FBI, CIA, and NSA came into existence and defined American intelligence activities. The role and activities of intelligence institutions is determined by the political context in which they function, and therefore the organization of the American political system will also be discussed. The course does not only deal with the American domestic debate on intelligence, but is also about American intelligence activities abroad, ranging from covert actions to change the political balance in other nations, to efforts to check the on-line and cell phone activities of individuals globally.As part of the course, students will write two papers based on either an FBI or CIA report, to gain insight into the quality of intelligence reports, but also into the challenges to gain reliable research results.', 'Teaching method', 'Lectures - on average 2 contact hours per week.', 'Time', 'See the timetable of this course on https://rooster.uva.nl.', 'Check the timetable before going to class, in case of changes.', 'Study materials', 'Mark M. Lowenthal, Intelligence: From Secrets to Policy. (Washington, DC: CQ Press, 2015), 6th edition (no earlier editions !), available in hardbound, paperback, and digital editions.Readings from the UvA digital library.', 'Cost', 'About 55 Euro.', 'Assessment and testing', 'Your final grade will be based on two tests (each 25% of the final grade or 50% total), and two written assignments (1500 and 2500 words, respectively 20% and 30% of your final grade). To pass you have to have a 5,5 grade average for the tests and for the final average grade (which includes the grades for the written assignments). There will be no make up options for the papers.', 'In the case of the tests, there will be a make-up test that covers the material of both previous tests (which means you cannot do a make up test for just one of the exams).', 'The questions on the exam will be based on the mandatory literature and the content of the lectures.', 'A review of an exam  should be given/requested within 20 days of publication of the mark. The date of the review is to be decided by the tutor(s).', 'Remarks', 'Please note the requirement for enrolling in this course.']

['Objectives', 'This course deals with interactions between light and molecules as
studied and employed by optical spectroscopy. Goal of the course is to
acquire a deeper knowledge of several spectroscopic principles and
techniques frequently applied in (bio)analytical chemistry.', 'Contents', 'The course will start with an introduction to photophysical principles
and fundamentals of molecular spectroscopy. Basic aspects of molecular
orbitals, electronic transitions and quantummechanics will be treated.
Basic properties of light and principal optical instrumentation will be
discussed. The fundamentals, practice and applications of electronic
spectroscopy (UV/Vis absorption, fluorescence, phosphorescence) and
vibrational spectroscopy (infrared, Raman) will be systematically
treated.', 'Registration', 'Information about procedures can be found at http://www.student.uva.nl/chem/az/item/course-registration.html.', 'Teaching method', 'Lecture (h): 30 hrs
Seminar/werkcollege (w): 12 hrs', 'Assessment and testing', 'Written examination.', 'Remarks', 'Recommended prior knowledge: Basic principles of molecular orbitals, energy levels and molecular vibrations. Basic experience with absorption spectrometry.']

Ondanks globalisering en de eenheidsgedachte van de Europese Unie oefent die erfenis van het nationalisme nog steeds een sterke invloed uit op het identiteitsbesef van de Europese burger. Tegenwoordig is het idee van de natie veelvuldig onderwerp van wetenschappelijke en politieke debatten. In de wetenschappelijke\xa0 analyse van het nationaal denken is het accent verschoven van een\xa0 intra-nationale kijk op de natie naar een meer vergelijkend en transnationaal perspectief. Daarbij spelen begrippen zoals cultuurtransfer (culturele overdracht) en cultureel geheugen een centrale rol.', 'Een transnationaal vergelijkende invalshoek, zoals die uitgerekend in de Europese Studies kan worden toegepast, geeft ons vaak een beter inzicht in de complexe culturele en politieke Europese werkelijkheid. Staten hebben multi-etnische gebieden genationaliseerd, en zowel dat proces als de uitkomst daarvan waren en blijven een bron van conflicten. Cultuurgrenzen vallen nooit samen met landsgrenzen. Binnen bestaande naties zijn er vaak verschillende regionale of etnische loyaliteiten – sommige traditioneel-provinciaal, andere modern-stedelijk (als gevolg van migratiepatronen in de laatste 50 jaar). Hoe gaan we om met dubbele nationaliteiten of de zogenaamde “hyphenated identities”? In\xa0 de publieke sfeer zijn er vaak heftige meningsverschillen en debatten over nationale symbolen en identiteiten. Wie hoort bij een natie en wie hoort er niet bij? Hoe stabiel zijn de kenmerken van nationale identiteit? Tot op welke hoogte kunnen natie-staten hun soevereiniteit en hun zogenaamde “identiteit” overdragen aan grotere verbanden? In deze cursus komen zulke vragen aan de orde met als doel het ontwikkelen van een succesvol scriptieonderwerp.', 'Werkvorm', 'Seminars: colleges bestaan uit een korte inleiding gevolgd door actieve groepsdiscussie over voorgeschreven teksten.', 'Rooster', 'Zie het rooster van dit vak op http://rooster.uva.nl', 'Studiemateriaal', 'ANDERSON, Benedict: Imagined Communities, London-New York: Verso, 2003, pp. 1-46, 67-111, 141-154.', 'ASSMANN, Aleida: Cultural Memory and Western Civilization, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011.', 'ERLL, Astrid: Memory in Culture, London: Palgrave Macmillan, 2011.', 'ERLL, Astrid-Nünning, Ansgar: A Companion to Cultural Memory Studies, Berlin-New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2010.', 'GELLNER, Ernest: Nationlism, London, Phoenix, 1997.', 'HOBSBAWM, Eric and Ranger, Terence: The Invention of Tradition, Cambridge: Canto, 2003, pp. 1-43, 101-164.', 'LEERSSEN, Joep: National Thought in Europe, Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2006.', "NORA, P.: 'Between Memory and History: Les Lieux de Mémoire', Representations 26, 1989, 7–25.", 'SMITH, Anthony D.: Nationalism, Cambridge: Polity Press, Key Concepts, 2005.', 'VERTOVEC, Steven: Transnationalism, Oxon: Routledge, 2009.', 'Toetsing en toetsdata', 'Overzichtswerkstuk (100% van het eindcijfer) en Scriptievoorstel (AVV).']

course_title: A City full of Gods: Roman Religion and Roman Imperialism
text: ['Contents', 'From the fourth century BC onwards, Rome developed from its modest origins as a small city-state on the banks of the Tiber into an empire that spanned the borders of the known world. According to writers like Livy and Cicero, much of this imperial success was based on religion. Like foreign communities that transformed from enemies into allies, the Romans also encountered foreign gods and were often quite willing to give them a place in their pantheon and in their city. Rome’s success was, in many ways, the gods’ success.', 'In this course, we will explore the various ways the conquest wars of the Roman Republic affected the religious landscape of the city of Rome, using a wide variety of literary and archaeological sources. We will analyze the solemn state rituals for Jupiter Optimus Maximus that preceded and succeeded all war efforts, but will also concentrate on the cult introductions that were the result of these efforts. What to think of the foreign and very mysterious goddess Magna Mater, who was worshipped in the form of a meteoric stone and was accompanied by ecstatic eunuch priests? Can we describe this pragmatic attitude towards old and new gods as a form of religious tolerance? And, if so, were there any limits to this tolerance?', 'Registration', 'As this course is being offered at the UvA, a UvANetID is required for registration. Please note that course registration periods at the UvA and VU differ. For a ‘step-by-step guide to course and exam registration’ and the ‘dates for course and exam registration’ please consult the ‘course and exam registration’-page via the ‘A-Z list’ of your MA programme on http://student.uva.nl/en/.', 'Teaching method', 'Seminars.', 'Time', 'See the timetable of this course on http://rooster.uva.nl', 'Study materials', 'To be announced.', 'Assessment and testing', 'Active participation and assignments (AVV)Take home exam: 25%Pilot: 10% Conference paper: 15%Response to conference paper (AVV)Final essay: 50%']

text: ['Objectives', 'After this course, students will be able to explain the perceptual principles that help guide the design of visualisations that communicate the intended message clearly. You will be able to explain how Gestalt laws influence the way people view and interpret visual displays of data, how people extract information from graphs, and what limitations are of the human visual system. In particular, you will be familiar with the Cleveland-McGill hierarchy, misleading and distorting effects of commonly made visualisation errors, perceptually effective encoding of quantities and categories, Tufte’s design principles, and Gestalt laws. You will be able to leverage these insights to enhance and optimise graphical display of data for efficient communication. You will have learned to work with various visualisation tools are popular in the data science community. These include R/ggplot, Tableau, and Shiny. As storytelling with graphs and charts often requires the rearrangement and slicing and dicing of data tables, you will also have learned to work with various data manipulation techniques using R, Excel, and SQL.', 'Contents', 'This course provides an introduction to principles for clear and effective communication of data analytic insights using visualisations. The job of visualisations is to present data in a perceptually organised way such that it allows the viewer to easily compare variables and understand correlations or relationships. The course emphasises perceptual principles that guide visualisation and provides hands-on experience with various techniques in more elaborate exercises and assignments with various types of software. Emphasis lies on making well thought through decisions and gaining experience with popular visualisation tools.', 'Recommended prior knowledge', 'Big Data Analytics', 'Required prior knowledge', 'Statistics, Programming Skills: R (or similar).', 'Teaching method', 'Online course videos, labs, and assignments.', 'Contact hours', 'Course weekTeaching methodHours/week1 - 4Werkcollege2', 'Study materials', 'To be announced on Blackboard.', 'Min/max participants', '25', 'Assessment and testing', 'Exam (50%) and a final project (50%). course_title: "Gentlemen Don’t Read Each Other’s Mail": United States Intelligence and National Security(Open UvA college)
text: ['Objectives', 'Introduce students to the challenges of intelligence analysis;Analyze the history of American concepts of national security and United States intelligence activities abroad;Study the rights and freedoms of citizens in the United States and the history of American domestic intelligence activities;Evaluate the role of the U.S. President and the uses of intelligence organizations and intelligence information.', 'Contents', 'This lecture series brings together the themes of national security and the right on privacy, two topics with a long history of debate, through the focus of United States intelligence work. Intelligence organizations are supposed to protect the nation against strategic and surprise attacks. The prevention of surprise attacks regularly failed, and in sometimes spectacular ways, such as with the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 and the 9/11 attacks in 2001. We will analyze what intelligence organizations try and can achieve, and how American politicians respond to so-called intelligence failures. One type of response is to increase intelligence activities, and gather more information on individual Americans. Such activities lead to questions about the role and power of the state, and the right to privacy. The Bill of Rights, and notably the Fourth Amendment, plays an important role in the discussion about the right of American citizens to their freedom and the permissibility of the activities of intelligence organizations.', 'The focus of the course is on twentieth and twenty-first century events, when organizations like the FBI, CIA, and NSA came into existence and defined American intelligence activities. The role and activities of intelligence institutions is determined by the political context in which they function, and therefore the organization of the American political system will also be discussed. Notably, but not uniquely, President Trump has shown that the relationship between president and intelligence organizations determines the quality of both intelligence work and policy making. The course does not only deal with the American domestic debate on intelligence, but is also about American intelligence activities abroad, ranging from covert actions to change the political balance in other nations, to efforts to check the on-line and cell phone activities of individuals globally.', 'As part of the course, students will write two papers based on either an FBI or CIA report, to gain insight into the quality of intelligence reports, but also into the challenges to gain reliable research results.', '', 'Registration', 'Zie ‘Vakaanmelding’ in de A-Z lijst van de bachelor Geschiedenis op student.uva.nl.', 'Teaching method', 'Lectures - on average 2 contact hours per week.', 'Time', 'See the timetable of this course on rooster.uva.nl.', 'Check the timetable before going to class, in case of changes.', 'Study materials', 'Mark M. Lowenthal, Intelligence: From Secrets to Policy. (Washington, DC: CQ Press, 2016), 7th edition (no earlier editions !), available in hardbound, paperback, and digital editions.Readings from the UvA digital library.', 'Cost', 'About 70 Euro.', 'Assessment and testing', 'Your final grade will be based on two tests (each 25% of the final grade or 50% total), and two written assignments (1500 and 2500 words, respectively 20% and 30% of your final grade). To pass you have to have a 5,5 grade average for the tests and for the final average grade (which includes the grades for the written assignments). There will be no make up options for the papers.', 'In the case of the tests, there will be a make-up test that covers the material of both previous tests (which means you cannot do a make up test for just one of the exams).', 'The questions on the exam will be based on the mandatory literature and the content of the lectures.', 'A review of an exam should be given/requested within 20 days of publication of the mark. The date of the review is to be decided by the tutor(s).', '', 'Remarks', 'Please note the requirement for enrolling in this course.']

Starting with the economic transformations, political debates, and social upheavals of the late 19th century, the course will trace developments in Russian and Soviet political, cultural, economic, and social life through revolution, war, modernization, and democratization. text: ['Objectives', 'After completing this course you', 'have a basic knowledge and understanding of the main cultural and historical developments in the Near East and Mediterranean between ca. 4000 and 300 BC are able to place these developments in time and space have a firm grasp of the chronological framework of this period know and can apply the essential terms, notions, concepts and stylistic characteristics current in contemporary scholarship in this field have experience in tackling cultural-historical problems from an interdisciplinary angle, using archaeological, textual and art historical sources.', 'Contents', 'This course offers you an overview of the major historical and cultural developments in the Mediterranean and the Near East between ca. 4000 and 300 BC. course_title: A global crisis of democracies? Change and continuity in 21st century politics
text: ['Objectives', '1. Students that have completed the research project successfully, have deepened their understanding of the central debates on the ways national and global politics is shaped by globalization and the economic crisis, especially in the shape of new issues, actors, and ideologies.', '2. After completion of the research project, students will be able to formulate a feasible research question (and related sub-questions), and indicate its theoretical and societal relevance.', '3. Following, students will be able to provide adequate definitions of central concepts as well as a clear explanation of the method they have employed.', '4. Student will also be able to carry out their research independently, and acquire the academic writing skills that allows them to present their results in a precise and comprehensive way.', 'Contents', 'All over the world politics is undergoing tumultuous change. British voters’ choice for Brexit was a profound shock for political elites all across Europe. Donald Trump might or might not reshape the world order. A set of emerging fault lines is (allegedly) changing the nature of politics, pitting nationalists against cosmopolitans, the young against the old, regions against the center, the ‘winners’ against the ‘losers’, immigrants against ‘natives’, illiberal democracies against liberal ones, trade against protectionism. Everywhere, citizens are making their voices heard in old and new ways, raising new issues, and voting for and founding new parties. How do these patterns of crisis and realignment reshape politics?', 'The overarching theme of this project is the way in which globalization and the economic crisis have affected, and keep affecting, national and global politics in a broad sense. We put extra emphasis on the rise of new issues, parties, actors, and movements, and how citizens cope with this. At the same time, we also investigate whether phenomena are as new as they sometimes seem.', 'This project thus facilitates students with interest in topics related to party behavior, populism, inequality, revolutions, emotions, voting behavior, welfare state politics, Euroscepticism, and other subjects connected to the theme of this course.', 'In this course students will write a thesis and will actively participate in class, which includes completing assignments and delivering several presentations. There will be about 8 substantive meeting for topical inspiration and exchange. After that students choose a research question and work independently with one-to-one meetings with the lecturer.', 'Registration', 'To be announced.', 'Time', 'Please see http://www.roosters.uva.nl → URL', 'Select “Add timetable”, than “Add course timetable” and search for either the course title or the course catalogue number.', 'Min/max participants', 'A maximum of 10 students.', 'Assessment and testing', 'The final deadline for handing in your thesis is Friday 22 June 2018']

['Objectives', '', 'The skills we train are: analysis of complex historical developments and critical writing; disciplined discussion and asking good questions. In the work groups we will read original documents that allow us to go into depth with issues introduced in the lecture. Also film material will put you into the shoes of Soviet citizens and their leaders. Students will regularly write short summaries of texts and documents, and develop a well-defined individual research project culminating in a term paper. While teaching is in English (as are all class readings), you can submit your written assignments also in Dutch or German.', 'Contents', '', 'This course will introduce students to the modern history of Russia beginning from the late imperial period to the present day.  Starting with the economic transformations, political debates, and social upheavals of the late 19th century, the course will trace developments in Russian and Soviet political, cultural, economic, and social life through revolution, war, modernization, and democratization. While focused on Russia proper, the course will pay particular attention to the imperial possessions in Central Asia, the Caucasus, and the western borderlands that were reincorporated as republics within the USSR and emerged as independent states after 1991.', 'Rather than giving students a chronological history of the late Russian empire and the USSR, the lectures introduce the students to a range of themes. This will help students understand not just what happened, but how our understanding of what happened has changed in recent decades, and gain an appreciation for the way different approaches provide new insights and complement each other. Students will thus explore the Russian/Soviet 20th century as:', 'Political HistoryImperial history: Nations, Minorities, DiasporasSocial History   Cultural History and the History of Culture  Economic and Environmental History International and Global History A History of Revolution, Dissent, and Reform', '', 'In the workgroups, students will also be encouraged to engage with the historical debates by reading and to draw their own conclusions by reading primary sources.', 'Registration', 'Information about course registration can be found here.', "If you are absent from the first class meeting without the lecturer's consent you lose your right to follow the course.", 'Contact hours', 'Course weekTeaching methodHours/week1 - 7Hoorcollege2 1 - 7Werkcollege2 8Tentamen2', 'Study materials', 'Textbook: Ronald Suny, The Soviet Experiment: Russia, the USSR, and the Successor States (2nd ed, 2010) Available at the Atheneum Bookstore.', 'Selections from the Suny book will be available on Canvas; you are strongly advised to purchase the book, as you will be able to return to it throughout your BA studies and beyond.', 'Besides your textbook reading, we will be discussing articles from scholarly journals and collections. They are there to help you understand how debates around key historical issues have developed and to see how history is written. These articles may be difficult to read at first, but it is absolutely imperative that you learn to engage such academic texts if you are going to become a serious student of history, politics, or any of the related disciplines. Your will get advice on reading such materials during the workgroup sessions.', 'You will notice a section called "supplementary reading." You are encouraged but not required to read these materials. If it is your week to present, however, you should have a look at the supplementary as well as required reading.', 'Primary Sources - on Canvas.', 'Students are encouraged to make full use of the web-site Seventeen Moments in Soviet History: http://soviethistory.msu.edu/', '', 'Assessment and testing', '', 'Oral participation in WG class discussions (10%)', 'Weekly essays (reading responses) to WG (40%)', 'Presentation in WG (10%)', 'Term paper (40%)', 'Oral Participation in the WG (10% of your grade)', 'Participation in class discussion will constitute 10% of your final mark. Your workgroup teacher will takes notes about your participation, in terms of both quality and quantity. To participate effectively you will need to do all of the required reading and pay attention during lectures.', 'As the WGs are designed as "grading moments" (toetsmomenten), participation is mandatory.', 'Short Essays (40% of your grade)', 'In preparation for the class discussions, you will be asked to write short essays (3-5 double spaced typed pages) answering ONE of the questions posted for that week. In writing your answer, you should draw on the key readings and primary sources (as well as on the lecture!), but you are also encouraged to consult the supplementary readings and materials available on the Seventeen Moments in Soviet History web-site. The essays are NOT meant to be a narrative summary, but essays that offer an answer to the question posed. They will be good practice for the term paper.', 'The essays should have a header with your name, the date, title of the course, and the subject of the week/of your response. Make sure you use the academic reference system when referencing texts (see below).']

course_title: 21st Century Power Shift: China’s Rise in the Global Political Economy
text: ['Objectives', "This course, and in particular its core task of preparing your Master's thesis will allow you to demonstrate:", "detailed substantive knowledge of the empirical implications of China's rise in the global political economy for other international actors, world regions, nation states or international relations more general;originality in developing and applying concepts and ideas within the research context of IR and IPE;the ability to apply your knowledge and understanding as well as problem solving abilities in \u2028a more specific topical area within the broader context of the field of study of IR (i.e. the topic of your thesis);", '', 'The course is designed to help students develop the following skills:', "the ability to integrate diverse knowledge and master the complexity of a larger research project as well as to formulate academically and politically relevant judgments that are sensitive to both the limitations and the ethical implications of the research; \u2028the ability to clearly communicate your conclusions as well as the knowledge and theoretical and methodological rationale underpinning these to a non-specialist academic audience in both speech and writing; \u2028the learning skills that would allow you to continue to study beyond the Master's level in a manner that is largely self-directed and autonomous; \u2028collaboration with other members in the group towards these goals.", 'Contents', "The emergence of China as a global power is arguably the most significant development in global politics and economics of the last two decades, and one which will continue to shape its evolution and growth long into the future. This research project therefore aims at supporting students who wish to write their Master's thesis on the political and economic dynamics of China’s rise and the implications of this process for both itself and other actors in the global political economy.", 'Although China’s significance in the world economy is now largely undisputed, relatively little is known about the determinants and making of China’s foreign economic policy, and about how this is shaping the global politics of capitalism in the 21st century world economy. The deep uncertainty and flux currently concerning leadership in global economic governance and the shifting locus of global economic power highlights the\xa0 importance of addressing questions such as:', "Does China represent a distinctive model of capitalism and political economy from that underpinning the ‘Western liberal order’?What explains China’s changing involvement and engagement with institutions of global\xa0 governance?How does China's increasing transnational economic engagement and diplomacy affect the domestic politics or the external behaviour of other states and actors?", '', "These general questions lead to a number of topics such as (but of course not limited to) the dynamics of US-China trade relations, the political consequences of the Belt and Road Initiative, the growth and influence of China’s fintech, artifical intelligence, and cybersecurity sectors, the impact of Chinese outbound investment on European and global labour and environmental standards, the rise of the Chinese Renminbi in the international monetary system, China's influence upon developmental models and trajectories across the Global South, and the emergence of new financial institutions such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB).", 'Registration', 'By submitting the registration form before Wednesday 28 November 2018 (midnight). The form will be sent to your student email account after the Thesis Market on Wednesday 21 November 2018.', 'Teaching method', '', 'In the first third of the semester, seminar meetings will be designed to provide the necessary background for working on the thesis. Each seminar will contain both a substantive discussion of specific topics and issues, and an element that focuses on relevant social science research methods. While studying and discussing this background, students should move towards identifying the specific topic of their thesis in cooperation with the instructor. At this stage, seminar meetings will be interactive but led by the instructor and incorporating lecture elements, and group discussion and exercises. Issues of research design and research management will be illustrated on the base of your work in progress.', 'The second two-thirds of the semester will largely be devoted to exchanging the information and experiences gained from work on the theses as well as to guidance in the process of research and writing. Seminar meetings will then take the form of short presentations by the participants, feedback, and discussion. Participants will additionally meet one-on-one with the instructor to discuss the more specific aspects of their individual thesis work.', 'Contact hours', 'Course weekTeaching methodHours/week6 - 26Werkcollege3', 'Min/max participants', 'Max. 10 students.', 'Assessment and testing', 'Please see the thesis manual (on Canvas).']

text: ['Objectives', 'This course will teach students to analyze topics involving identity, cultural diversity, and the dynamics of Western and non-Western civilizations in a criticalStudents will develop a historical understanding of Europe’s colonial and imperial past through the changes brought about in the self-image ofStudents will also become familiar with various theoretical and cultural-philosophical terms and perspectives which have been major influences on contemporary thought about (post)colonialism.The relationship of colonial discourse to literature and visual arts will be focused on.', '', '', 'Students will learn to:', 'read and analyze critical textsvisit exhibitions and analyze them critically hence getting the chance to apply current concepts of (post)colonial theory to specific cultural objects and their presentationsdevelop presentation and discussion skillsgive peer-review feedbackvisit museums/ galleries and have a critical look at what is represented to them', '', '', 'Contents', 'In its present identity crisis Europe seems to forget its past. Questions about who is or can', 'be European have become increasingly urgent. Mounting anxieties about culture and', 'identity produce strong narratives of a Europe in peril, whose people are threatened', 'by an imagined influx of racialised and culturalised others who do not fit. Such', 'narratives hinge on a denial of Europe’s histories of colonization and decolonization.', '', 'This seminar will discuss Europe’s colonial and imperial past, and its consequences and relations to our present and future of Europe. text: ['Objectives', "Het verkrijgen van een overzicht van civil-society activisme en internationale diplomatie op het terrein van milieu- en klimaatvraagstukken sinds de jaren '60. - Zelfstandig een klein onderzoek uitvoeren, gebaseerd op zelfstandig literatuuronderzoek en met gebruik van primair bronnenmateriaal; neerslag in de vorm van een historisch onderbouwde reflectie op heden en toekomst.", '- Het kritisch lezen van, en constructief reflecteren op, het werk van medestudenten in de context van project-presentaties.', 'Contents', 'De grote paradox, en uitdaging, van onze tijd is dat de manier waarop de moderne wereld sinds de negentiende eeuw grotere en breder gedeelde welvaart heeft gecreëerd (en nog altijd creëert) tegelijk zulke grote ecologische en klimatologische veranderingen heeft veroorzaakt (en nog altijd veroorzaakt) dat op afzienbare termijn de mensheid, en de ecosystemen waarbinnen zij overleeft, in hun bestaan wordt bedreigd.', '', "Sinds de mensheid zich hiervan bewust is gaan worden, heeft er een nauwe band bestaan tussen wat lokaal gebeurt en internationaal. course_title: 12 jaar aan de wereld timmeren - De Biënnales van Venetië
text: ['Leerdoelen', 'In deze onderzoekswerkgroep leer je', 'hoe je een onderzoek opzet en uitvoert;hoe je een onderzoeksveld afbakent en een werkbare probleemstelling formuleert;welke methodes bruikbaar zijn voor jouw onderzoek;hoe je structuur aanbrengt in je argumentatie.', '', 'Dit leer je door binnen het aangebrachte kader een individueel onderzoeksonderwerp te kiezen en uit te voeren. Maar ook', 'Peer review – anderen helpen door evaluatie en commentaar.', '', 'Er is dus zowel een inhoudelijk leerdoel: kennis te vergaren over een bepaalde periode in de kunstgeschiedenis (2007-2019), een bepaalde tentoonstellingsvorm (biennales), en bepaalde hedendaagse concepten (kunst en wereld, kunst en kennis); als een praktisch leerdoel: leren onderzoek opzetten, uitvoeren en evalueren.', 'Inhoud', 'In 2001 was Harald Szeemann curator van de eerste Biennale in Venetie in het nieuwe millennium. De titel was Plateau of Humankind. Op dat Plateau bracht Szeemann kunstwerken en objecten bijeen uit zoveel mogelijk regionen en culturen in de wereld. Rodin’s Denker had hierin een veelzeggende plaats. Iedere nieuwe curator van de Biennale formuleert een thema, en vooral sinds 2007 zien we dat het Wereld thema vaste voet aan de grond heeft gekregen. Al in 2005 organiseerde Robert Storr het symposium Where Art Worlds meet: Multiple Modernities and the Global Salon. Hij was de curator van de Biennale in 2007 – Think with the Senses, Feel with the Mind. Een heldere aanwijzing voor de bijdrage en rol van de kunst in de wereld. In 2009 had de Biennale de titel Making Worlds. Curator Daniel Birnbaum schreef: ‘a work of art is more than an object, more than a commodity. It represents a vision of the world (…) it can be seen as world-making’. De Biennale in 2013 heette The Encyclopedic Palace \xa0(curator Massimilio Gioni) en wilde het verlangen tonen ‘om alles te weten over de transformatieve macht van de verbeelding’. In 2015 werd de politieke betekenis van kunst expliciet zichtbaar gemaakt in Okwui Enwezor’s Biennale, All the World’s Futures. De curator in 2017 (Christine Macel) was misschien wat terughoudender en vroeg zich af wat voor invloed de spanningen in de wereld hebben op kunstenaars. De Biennale 2019 is bij het schrijven van deze tekst nog niet begonnen, maar curator Ralph Rugoff geeft zijn Biennale (en ons) een chinees gezegde mee: May you live in interesting times. Een tijd van alternatieve feiten en ‘post-truth’.', 'De thema’s van de Biennales hebben alles te maken met tendensen in de kunst en in de kunstpraktijk (artistic research) om aan de wereld te timmeren. In de afgelopen 20 jaar zijn er talloze nieuwe nationale paviljoens bijgekomen uit de hele wereld. Maar dit roept ook interessante vragen op: hoe kun je dit idee van natiestaten kortsluiten met het idee van een open en fluïde wereld? Zeker als de kunstpraktijk die grenzen vaak juist helemaal niet belangrijk vindt (maar misschien soms ook wel). En wat is dan de rol of functie van de kunst en kunstenaar in de wereld? Maar ook institutioneel gezien: wat is de rol van de(ze) Biennale voor de kunst en voor onze reflectie op de kunst. En niet in de laatste plaats hoe dragen kunstenaars bij aan kennis over de wereld, over cultuur, politiek, wetenschap?', 'Deze Biennales (de thema’s en concepten, curatoren, kunstenaars en werken) vormen het kader van deze onderzoekswerkgroep. Na een introductie van het kader, en het gezamenlijk bespreken van verschillende aspecten ervan, gaan studenten zelf aan de slag met een individueel onderwerp. Er zal een lijst met onderzoeksonderwerpen beschikbaar zijn. Eigen inbreng is ook mogelijk (na overleg).', 'Aanbevolen voorkennis', 'Wetenschapsfilosofie is geen ingangseis, maar wordt ten zeerste aanbevolen.', 'Aanmelden', 'Informatie over de vakaanmelding en de vakaanmeldperiodes vind je hier.Bij overinschrijving hebben (derdejaars)studenten Kunstgeschiedenis voorrang.', 'Werkvorm', '1x 2 uur per week college. De onderzoekswerkgroep bestaat uit 2 hoorcolleges, werkgroepsbijeenkomsten en zelfstudie (individueel onderzoek). In de periode van zelfstudie zullen er feedback bijeenkomsten zijn.', 'Studiemateriaal', 'Studiemateriaal zal voor het begin van de werkgroep op Canvas beschikbaar zijn.', 'Toetsing en toetsdata', 'Toetsing geschiedt door middel van enkele kleine opdrachten, een pitch presentatie, een onderzoeksverslag.']

course_title: "Stop right here!": The Body, Borders and State Power
text: ['Objectives', 'Become acquainted with recent sociological puzzles and debates in critical border and migration studiesBecome acquainted with a selection of recent academic publications on the sociology and anthropology of the stateBecome able to think with black and mestiza feminism about the state and the lawBecome able to think with transgender studies about “juridical myths” of bodily integrity', '', 'Develop a sociological perspective on mobility and the body regarding intersecting infrastructures of power.', '', 'Practice sociological writing skills and qualitative interview techniques', 'Contents', 'Students will be motivated to critically think about state power and its borders, rather as spaces with depth, spaces that shift shape in the encounter with variously differentiated bodies. For some people crossing the border is smooth. The line seems to disappear when having ‘crossed’ it by, for example, leaving an airport. For others, borders are spaces of blockage and suspicion, they will not disappear and they continuously run the risk of (re)encountering the border. For them the border materializes again and again: in the form of a police officer checking a person’s legal status or a routine check that could lead to detention and deportation. Hence, some are made to feel safe and some feel anxious when being interpellated by one of the multiple forms of state power.', 'We will study these state and border infra/structures in their inherent relations to other contingent systems of power – like white supremacy, sexism and coloniality – that differentiate bodies into ‘other’ and ‘self’, into ‘suspect’ and ‘trustworthy’, into ‘belonging’ and ‘unbelonging’. In order to do this, we will read texts ranging from critical border studies to the sociology of the state, to Science and Technology studies on (racial) works of classification, to black and mestiza feminism and into the field of gender and sexuality studies. This will help us engage with questions of how the state bounds and borders movement, classifies bodies in order to continuously imagine a national self. As such, this course is not staged to study ‘the migrant’ as the other out there, but as a phenomenon shaped, policed and practiced to maintain a sense of (securitized) national self.', 'Registration', 'Through Selfservice SIS.', 'Teaching method and contact hours', 'We will have once a week a seminar in which we welcome guest lecturers, and once a week we will meet for a tutorial in which we read parts of the texts together. We will connect our exchange of knowledge to the larger theme of the state, the border and its work of differentiating bodies. We will also have a special seminar with a (former) immigration officer on the affective and emotional side of his work. He will challenge all of us to think about the hard decisions he had to make. \xa0We will not get away easily with attaching all accountability onto him as we, currently in this part of the world, are all in different ways part of his state work. Near the end of the course, students will present and discuss their ideas for their final paper.', 'Our gatherings are both online and on campus (hybrid teaching)', 'Study materials', 'Various articles and chapters from, among others, Simone Browne, Talal Asad, Christina Sharpe, Alexander Weheliye, Stephano Harney, Willem Schinkel, Amade M’charek, Gloria Anzaldua, Nicholas De Genova, Angela Davis, Susan Stryker, bell hooks and Miriam Ticktin. Made available on Canvas.', '', 'Assessment', 'Participation in tutorials and seminars: 10 %Annotated bibliography of 15 texts we have been readings (40 %)Final essay of between 2000 to 4000 words (50%)', 'Remarks', 'Plagiarism and fraud: All exams and papers will be checked for plagiarism and fraud (and when found out, consequences will be serious). For university regulations and procedures in case of plagiarism and fraud see: https://student.uva.nl/social-sciences/shared/studentensites/uva-studentensite/en/az/plagiarism-and-fraud/plagiarism-and-fraud.html.']

['Contents', 'Tutorials are small but intense 6 ECTS classes that you organize yourself – following your own research interests and in agreement with the availability and expertise of the teaching staff. These tutorials will enable you to engage in an intensive exchange with the research of staff members. The department offers three kinds of tutorials: regular tutorials, colloquia-as-tutorials, and internships-as-tutorials.', 'You should follow three tutorials. The tutorials often pave the way for your thesis, thus allowing prolonged engagement with a given topic under the direct supervision of an experienced researcher. You have to register the tutorials you follow on the Canvas site of the research master.', 'Regular tutorial', 'Ideally this tutorial consists of 2-5 students, who meet the teacher between 4 and 6 times for intense discussions of their readings. The average amount of reading that you are expected to do for a tutorial can be around 4 monographs or 12 key articles. This may of course vary due to the difficulty of the primary texts. Although the study efforts are flexible and can be determined by the respective teacher (presentations, minutes, reading reports etc. are all acceptable) there needs to be at least one written piece (worked out presentation, paper). The tutorial is graded with a mark.', 'Colloquium-as-tutorial', 'The Philosophy department hosts three recurring research colloquia – the PPA Colloquium, the DIP Colloquium, and the APES Seminar –, in which national and international researchers are invited to present their work. Meetings are approximately once a month. The Philosophy and Public Affairs colloquium focusses on political philosophy and ethics, the Discourse and Philosophy colloquium on philosophy of language and logic and the Amsterdam Philosophy Encounters Science & Society seminar on philosophy of science. Attendance of these research seminars during one semester can also count as a tutorial and is highly recommended when these are within your field of interest. Examination conditions are decided upon in consultation with the coordinator of the research colloquia (PPA: G.vanDonselaar@uva.nl & R.Celikates@uva.nl; DIP: L.Incurvati@uva.nl; APES: F.Russo@uva.nl)', 'Internship-as-tutorial', 'An important objective in the research master is to acquire the practical skills needed for performing scientific research in philosophy. The goal of an internship-as-tutorial is to provide you with the opportunity to acquire practical skills in carrying out academic research.\xa0For the internships you participate in projects of the philosophy department’s staff, like preparing an academic conference, editing an academic volume or journal issue, or assisting in academic teaching.\xa0Depending on the internship. Some internships might require substantial knowledge of a specific philosophical field of research.\xa0Vacant internships for the first semester are announced in May and internships for the second semester are announced in November.', 'Registration', 'Information about course registration can be found here.']

text: ['Objectives', '- Obtain knowledge of the emergence of environmental degradation and climate change as subjects of transnational activism and international relations since the middle of the 20th century.', '- Gain insight into the politics of environmental protection and collective action against climate change since the 1960s, globally and in various parts of the world.', '- Apply historical knowledge and historical thinking on these issues in a contemporary case-study, using scholarly literature and historical and contemporary primary sources.', '- Present the preliminary results of the research to other members of the group; provide and receive peer-review; present the end-result of the research in a wider context, with commentary from members of the UvA-ASH research group Environment & Society: contestation & governance.', '', 'Contents', 'The way the modern world since the 19th century has created wealth and prosperity--a carbon-based economy--has caused ecological and climatological problems so severe that most of this progress will be at risk for people all over the world in this century. This is the great paradox, and challenge, of our time: what has made many people thrive, and what others hope will do the same for them, now threatens most of what has been accomplished.', '', 'As humanity has become aware of the threat, there has been a close connection between on the one hand, what happens locally, regionally, and nationally, and, on the other hand, what individuals, groups, and governments have been able to accomplish inter- and transnationally.', '', "Without a scientific consensus there can be no basis for action; without local and transnational activism, there's little incentive for meaningful diplomacy. These three aspects: emergence of a scientific consensus on the important environmental and climate challenges; civil society activism, but also skepticism and denial; and international diplomacy will be central in this course for the period since the 1960s. In light of the global nature of the challenges, the emphasis will be on international and transnational aspects.", '', 'This is a history course. As historians we believe that contemporary challenges cannot be understood without knowledge of their history, and that historical thinking is indispensable as a basis for meaningful action in the present. The recent history of action and inaction on environmental and climate questions is particularly contested, and it will be one of our tasks to grapple with it. History will not provide simple prescriptions for action on the difficult questions. Still, the goal for the research projects is to find convincing ways to have historical research inform present-day debates.', 'Teaching method and contact hours', 'Twice-weekly seminar meetings; common readings and discussions; peer-review of research plans; presentation of research results at a public forum.', 'Remarks', 'Lanquage of instruction will be English']
